ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the factors of production, the labor market and factor market, and the interaction between economic agents.

I learned a lot about both consumer and producer economic theory in this class. Taking economics as a whole definitely helps you think more rationally, in terms of opportunity costs and things like that. This class is very math-centric, it has to be to be a QR credit, so I think what I mostly developed was just how to do economic math problems.
ability to think like an economist and the basics of microeconomics: supply, demand, profit maximization, utility maximization, budget constraints, externalities
Supply and demand, profit/cost maximization/minimization, labor and capital markets, behavioral finance

This was a crash course in micro, so I definitely learned a lot, but it was mostly short term memory because there was an exam every two weeks. Tolga also occasionally will give life lessons so those were fun.
I learned about how the market works and some theory behind it
Basic microeconomics
I learned the foundational principles of microeconomics while learning real like applications of this concepts as well.
I learned that im actually very passionate about economics! Specifically, behavioral economics.
I learned the basics of micro-economic theory: how consumers and suppliers interact, various market structures, etc.
Having never taken Economics before, I learned a great deal about how economics functions, the philosophy/mindset behind it, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course was very intense over the summer, but this is just an inevitable result of the compressed timeline. Tolga was a phenomenal professor and the course was well-structured.

The strengths of this class are that the expectations are laid out for you very clearly. The problem sets are straightforward and there are office hours for all of them. If you understand these and go to all of the review sessions, you should do well on the exams too. The biggest weakness is the sheer amount of work required for each class. There are both readings and lecture videos on top of the 2 hour classes, and it kinda ended up taking up my whole life.  Also, the live sessions tend to be a bit rushed, plus redundant after having watching the videos and doing the readings.
could be improved with additional activities in class to get everyone more involved. strength was that the content across lectures, homework, and exams was consistent and fair

Much of what was covered in the lecture was stated again during section, making the section not as useful at times. I think that rather than doing a repeat of the lectures, going over problems and examples building on top of what we learned from the lectures would be more useful.

The weaknesses of this course are definitely how fast it is. It's only 5 weeks and the entire semester is crammed in there. It was a total of 10 days of class, but because of the exams, we really only received 8 days of instruction so there was a lot of independent studying. Honestly, this class should be restricted to people who have an econ backgroundat least for this 5 week summer course.

Strenghts: interesting material that is important to understanding the world, Prof. Koker is a very genuine, likeable guy who is always willing to help students

Weaknesses: course moves too fast and students need to spend extensive out-of-class time digesting material, synchronous lectures do not help a lot as they cover the material superficially (%95 of learning is done watching recorded lectures and reading the textbook). Unfortunately, even though Prof. Koker is a great guy, he spends a large portion of class time going on unrelated tangents, which makes the situation worse. There are way too few office hour sessions hosted weekly (for comparison, classes running in the fall or spring generally have 3-4 office hour sessions/week. This summer class, which moves about 2.5x times faster, has only 1 office hour session for week, which lasts only an hour). 

How it could be improved: 

1. My suggestion would be to have slides with the necessary topics as well as graphs, figures, etc. prepared in advance for the synchronous lectures, so that no time is wasted drawing them, and so that the material flows in a cohesive way. This would also help reduce Prof. Koker from being sidetracked, because we would know that we have to finish all the slides by the end of lecture. 

2. Increase the number of office hour sessions to 3 sessions/week.
strengths: having more support in order to understand any and all concepts.

The course was very thorough, with lots of content crammed into just five weeks-- I felt like I learned a lot, but it sometimes felt like too much to adequately wrap my mind around in time for the exams. Overall I enjoyed the course, and the Professor was often able to tie the theory back to pertinent real-life examples.

I think the textbook assigned was really great and that both the homework and test matched wonderfully with what was taught. My main complaint is that the course could feel a bit redundant between the textbook, the online lectures, and the synchronous zoom classes  much of the content, particularly for the online lectures and zoom classes, was repeated.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this to any student willing to put in the time-- I spent around 40 hours per week on this course, and studied really rigorously to compensate for the two class days lost to exams.
I would! The math isn't hard, and I think taking economics provides you with important life skills, even if you're not planning on studying it. Just be willing to put in the time.
Yes, I would recommend this course to any yale student and not just those who are thinking about an econ degree because the material and principles are  applicable to every day life.

I would only recommend this course to someone who already knows a decent amount about econ or is really good at math. If you don't have one of those (unfortunately I had neither) this class will be hell for you. The workload is also extremely high. There are a minimum of 4 psets you have to do over the term, with a midterm and a final. In addition to having to watch approximately 3-6 hours of lectures a week, with live classes as well. It's a lot. I do not recommend this class to anyone who is only slightly interested in econ or thinks this will be an easy class. If you are not good at math or econ, this class will be work.
Yes, because you'll learn a lot of things that are important in other fields too.
I would, if there are way more office hour sessions weekly and if synchronous lecture time is used more wisely.

absolutely i think this course is great because you can focus your energy on this specific course and the professor/TF do everything they can to make sure you are clear on the concepts you need to know.
Yes -- I found it to be super rewarding.
It's a very accelerated micro course: you'll learn a lot very quickly, but take it if you find it interesting!
Yes. I think the course did a great job teaching the fundamentals of economics. While I think the course could be perhaps more efficient or clearer at times, it was generally interesting and useful.
